Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor arranged a short meeting in an otherwise packed day.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for the meeting with Dr. Patel, my mentor. He’d squeezed me into his schedule for a quick check-in, and I knew how rare that was. I grabbed my bag, rehearsing the questions I wanted to ask, when my brother’s name flashed on the screen. He never called during the day unless it was serious. I answered, and his voice was shaky—he’d just gotten some bad news and needed to talk. We’d always promised to be there for each other, no matter what. But Dr. Patel’s time was precious, and I’d already rescheduled twice. My brother’s words tumbled out, raw and urgent, while the clock ticked closer to my meeting. I felt torn, guilt gnawing at me from both sides. I wanted to be the brother he could count on, but I also didn’t want to let down the mentor who believed in me. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, phone pressed to my ear, caught between two promises I didn’t want to break.
